title: Homework_02
text:
Mostly testing if this works.

x<- c(2,3,4)
y<- c(5,4,3)

print (x)

[1] 2 3 4

title: Homework_03
text:
Q3
Set.seed sets the random coordinates to a value so they don’t change on you. Using the formulas provided by the textbook I was able to convert to radius and theta.

set.seed (6)
coords<- (runif(2))
print(coords)

[1] 0.6062683 0.9376420

r<- sqrt(coords[1]^2 +coords[2]^2)
theta<-atan(coords[2]/ coords[1])
polar<- c(r=r,theta=theta)
print(polar)

        r     theta 
1.1165723 0.9968233 



Q4
I updated the vector to the line for the arc according to the homework. Then I searched the vector for the character “aphid” to find the number in line. The aphid is 3th in line.

queue<- c("sheep", "fox", "owl", "ant")
queue [5]<- "serpent"
queue [6]<- "sheep"
queue [1]<- "donkey"
queue<- queue [-5]
queue<- queue [-3]
queue <- append(queue,'aphid', after = 2)

which (queue== "aphid")

[1] 3

print(queue)

[1] "donkey" "fox"    "aphid"  "ant"    "sheep" 




Q5
v removes the integers where they are divisible by 2,3, and 7. The sequence was made and then the integers were removed from the sequence.

q<-c(seq(1:100))
v<- q[which(q %% 2 != 0 & q %% 3 != 0 & q %% 7 != 7)]

print (v)

 [1]  1  5  7 11 13 17 19 23 25 29 31 35 37 41 43 47 49 53 55 59 61 65 67 71 73
[26] 77 79 83 85 89 91 95 97

title: Homework_04
text:
Homework 4


Gwen Phillips


Feb 4 2026
###________________________
Q1. The sample function provides a random number within the constraints provided. The t() function transposes the matrix or data frame referenced within the parenthesis. To calculate the sum and mean of certain rows utilize the brackets within the fuction.

n_dims<- sample(3:10, 1)
my_vec<- 1:(n_dims^2)

s<- sample(my_vec, 4)
m<- matrix(s, nrow=2, ncol=2)
print(m)

     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    9    2
[2,]    6    1

###transposing the matrix
t(m)

     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    9    6
[2,]    2    1

print(m)

     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    9    2
[2,]    6    1

### finding matrix sums and means
sum(m[1,])

[1] 11

mean(m[1,])

[1] 5.5

sum(m[2,])

[1] 7

mean(m[2,])

[1] 3.5

###eigen function
e<- eigen(m,symmetric=T)
print(e)

eigen() decomposition
$values
[1] 12.211103 -2.211103

$vectors
           [,1]       [,2]
[1,] -0.8816746  0.4718579
[2,] -0.4718579 -0.8816746

#### These are doubles since they have decimals
typeof(e)

[1] "list"

### These are considered a list

Q2. Create matrixes, vectors, and lists, then identify them using the typeof() function. Then isolate certain values within those and creat lists and vectors.

### create a matrix
my_matrix<- matrix(runif(16),nrow=4, ncol=4)
my_matrix

          [,1]      [,2]       [,3]      [,4]
[1,] 0.3308521 0.4168108 0.05813091 0.3689673
[2,] 0.6671218 0.9157745 0.96130762 0.9356697
[3,] 0.6994584 0.4623280 0.07267431 0.1073813
[4,] 0.3513313 0.1131275 0.72270007 0.1474123

### create a T/F vector
v<- sample(1:1000, 100)
my_logical<- v>=500
my_logical

  [1] FALSE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE
 [13] FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE
 [25]  TRUE FALSE  TRUE FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE
 [37] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE
 [49]  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE
 [61]  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE
 [73] FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE
 [85]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE FALSE
 [97] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE

### create a vector of 26 random letters
my_letters<- sample(letters, 26)
my_letters

 [1] "u" "p" "i" "c" "h" "e" "r" "t" "g" "a" "d" "y" "f" "w" "m" "b" "v" "l" "q"
[20] "s" "x" "o" "k" "j" "n" "z"

### create a list 
list<-list(my_matrix[2,2],my_logical[2],my_letters[2])

print(list)

[[1]]
[1] 0.9157745

[[2]]
[1] TRUE

[[3]]
[1] "p"

### confirm the list
typeof(list) ###it is a list

[1] "list"

### create a vec of the list elements
vec<- c(0.01371653, "TRUE", "l")
### what data type is it
typeof(vec) ### character

[1] "character"


Q3 Set.seed function allows random numbers to be saved so they don’t change in later formulas. Data frames can be created using the cbind function and the which function can highight specific elements of the data. The order function reorders that data frame in numeric or alphabetical order depending on the type of vectors.

### create 26 values between 0 and 10
set.seed(321)
my_unis<- runif(26, min=0, max=10)
my_unis

 [1] 9.5589376 9.3728552 2.3822045 2.5507364 3.9051197 3.4117986 4.5238060
 [8] 2.8993282 4.5067322 8.0659572 6.0572107 3.6284109 7.6633847 0.4508695
[15] 5.9217188 2.0163219 6.3273803 4.0358999 2.9050341 6.4045901 6.3596776
[22] 9.8987845 9.3117401 4.8550475 5.7468926 7.5123825

### create a vector of 26 letters
set.seed(123)
my_letters<- sample(LETTERS, 26)
my_letters

 [1] "O" "S" "N" "C" "J" "R" "K" "E" "X" "Y" "W" "T" "I" "L" "U" "M" "P" "H" "B"
[20] "G" "Z" "A" "F" "V" "D" "Q"

### create a df
df<- data.frame(x= my_unis,y= my_letters)
### Enter NAs into 4 random rows
df[sample(nrow(df), 4), 1]<- NA 

### intentify which rows have a missing variable
which(!complete.cases(df))

[1]  7 11 17 21

### reorder to aphabetical
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

df_alphabetic<- df[order(df[, 2]), ]
 print(df_alphabetic)

           x y
22 9.8987845 A
19 2.9050341 B
4  2.5507364 C
25 5.7468926 D
8  2.8993282 E
23 9.3117401 F
20 6.4045901 G
18 4.0358999 H
13 7.6633847 I
5  3.9051197 J
7         NA K
14 0.4508695 L
16 2.0163219 M
3  2.3822045 N
1  9.5589376 O
17        NA P
26 7.5123825 Q
6  3.4117986 R
2  9.3728552 S
12 3.6284109 T
15 5.9217188 U
24 4.8550475 V
11        NA W
9  4.5067322 X
10 8.0659572 Y
21        NA Z

### find mean of col 1
mean_df<- mean(df[,1]) 
print(mean_df)

[1] NA
